title: Solutions of quadratic, cubic, and quartic equations

blocks.name: quad2
blocks.content: The quadratic equation, without specifying the particular branch ` D ` to the square root. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 23-Apr-2015.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: quad
blocks.content: The quadratic equation. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 23-Apr-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm quad(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wb(wceq(co(co(c0, cmul, co(c1, cexp, nat2)), caddc, co(co(c2, cmul, c1), caddc, c3)), nat0), wo(wceq(c1, co(co(cneg(c2), caddc, cfv(csqrt, c4)), cdiv, co(nat2, cmul, c0))), wceq(c1, co(co(cneg(c2), cmin, cfv(csqrt, c4)), cdiv, co(nat2, cmul, c0))))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c0, nat0))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wceq(c4, co(co(c2, cexp, nat2), cmin, co(nat4, cmul, co(c0, cmul, c3)))))
} = {
  quad2(c0, c1, c2, c3, cfv(csqrt, c4), w0)
  sqrtcld(c4, w0)
  eqtrd(co(cfv(csqrt, c4), cexp, nat2), co(co(c2, cexp, nat2), cmin, co(nat4, cmul, co(c0, cmul, c3))), c4, w0)
  sqsqrtd(c4, w0)
  eqeltrd(c4, cc, co(co(c2, cexp, nat2), cmin, co(nat4, cmul, co(c0, cmul, c3))), w0)
  subcld(co(c2, cexp, nat2), co(nat4, cmul, co(c0, cmul, c3)), w0)
  sqcld(c2, w0)
  sylancr(w0, wcel(co(nat4, cmul, co(c0, cmul, c3)), cc), wcel(nat4, cc), wcel(co(c0, cmul, c3), cc))
  4cn()
  mulcld(c0, c3, w0)
  mulcl(nat4, co(c0, cmul, c3))
}

thm 1cubrlem() {

blocks.name: dcubic1lem
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ dcubic1 and ~ dcubic2 : simplify the cubic equation under the substitution ` X = U - M / U ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 26-Apr-2015.)

blocks.name: dcubic2
blocks.content: Reverse direction of ~ dcubic . Given a solution ` U ` to the "substitution" quadratic equation ` X = U - M / U ` , show that ` X ` is in the desired form. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 25-Apr-2015.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: dcubic
blocks.content: Solutions to the depressed cubic, a special case of ~ cubic . (The definitions of ` M , N , G , T ` here differ from ~ mcubic by scale factors of ` -u 9 ` , ` 5 4 ` , ` 5 4 ` and ` -u 2 7 ` respectively, to simplify the algebra and presentation.) (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 26-Apr-2015.)

  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, cc))

  -| wi(w0, wcel(c5, cc))

blocks.name: mcubic
blocks.content: Solutions to a monic cubic equation, a special case of ~ cubic . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 24-Apr-2015.)

blocks.name: cubic2
blocks.content: The solution to the general cubic equation, for arbitrary choices ` G ` and ` T ` of the square and cube roots. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 23-Apr-2015.)

blocks.name: cubic
blocks.content: The cubic equation, which gives the roots of an arbitrary (nondegenerate) cubic function. Use ~ rextp to convert the existential quantifier to a triple disjunction. This is Metamath 100 proof #37. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 26-Apr-2015.)

blocks.name: binom4
blocks.content: Work out a quartic binomial. (You would think that by this point it would be faster to use ~ binom , but it turns out to be just as much work to put it into this form after clearing all the sums and calculating binomial coefficients.) (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 6-May-2015.)

blocks.name: dquart
blocks.content: Solve a depressed quartic equation. To eliminate ` S ` , which is the square root of a solution ` M ` to the resolvent cubic equation, apply ~ cubic or one of its variants. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 6-May-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm dquart(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, wff w0) {

  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c4, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wceq(c7, co(co(nat2, cmul, c4), cexp, nat2)))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c7, nat0))

  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wceq(co(co(co(c7, cexp, nat3), caddc, co(co(nat2, cmul, c1), cmul, co(c7, cexp, nat2))), caddc, co(co(co(co(c1, cexp, nat2), cmin, co(nat4, cmul, c3)), cmul, c7), caddc, cneg(co(c2, cexp, nat2)))), nat0))

blocks.name: quart
blocks.content: The quartic equation, writing out all roots using square and cube root functions so that only direct substitutions remain, and we can actually claim to have a "quartic equation". Naturally, this theorem is ridiculously long (see ~ quartfull ) if all the substitutions are performed. This is Metamath 100 proof #46. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 6-May-2015.)
